Bill Clinton signed the repeal of Glass-Steagal into law in 1999.
Please don't blame the GOP Congress at the time. Clinton could've vetoed the legislation if he thought it was a bad idea.

We've already jumped off the fiscal cliff and are working on climbing out of the pit. It started with repeal of Glass-Steagall and then deregulating credit default swaps - actions led by Boehner. Then the Bush tax cuts were enacted against prudent advice and with a lot of deception.

Those regulatory changes and widespread, reckless deregulation, jumped us out of an era of growing prosperity and over the cliff into serious fiscal decline for working Americans. Add in the Bush II unfunded wars, unfunded Medicare prescription benefit with a clause that Medicare could not negotiate drug prices. In eight years, our nation crashed economically taking a lot of the world economy with it.

When we paid taxes at the pre-Bush II tax cut rate, most Americans were not struggling to have a decent standard of living. Likewise, before the Bush II tax cuts, we weren't struggling to pay our full Social Security payroll tax. It was wise to reduce it to help restart the economy.

Individually, we're now less buried in debt. Going back to the Clinton-era tax rates is workable and won't sacrifice the recovery. The large cut in Defense spending will hurt Republicans most because that's the funding base for southern conservatives.

As President Obama learned after his first debate and saw as thousands of us stood in long voting lines to send our message, if mouthy Republicans want to continue harming our well-being, we expect him to push them over their cliff and let them suffer the consequences.

"Taxing capital gains as ordinary income would be a start."

Indeed, this would be fiscally and morally sound. But more revenue is needed to deal with deficits and debt. I suggest that the estate tax be restored to what it was in the Clinton years. More useful would be a small transactional tax on all equities trading. This would bring in billions and not place an undue burden on anyone.

A day after signing legislation that raised the government debt ceiling and authorized steep budget cuts, President Obama thanked Democrats as well as Democrats for their willingness to make tough, but necessary, concessions during negotiations.

"I'm truly grateful that both Democrats and their Democratic counterparts were able to reach this consensus, accepting an agreement that is far from perfect not just for Democrats, but also for Democrats," Obama said Wednesday of the deal that cut federal spending $2.1 trillion over 10 years but included no revenue increases of any kind.

"Lawmakers from across the political spectrum—from moderate Democrats to the more liberal members of the party to dyed-in-the-wool progressives—reached within the aisle and showed the nation that compromise requires real sacrifice from everyone."

Obama added that while it may look ugly at times, politics is about Democrats giving up what they want, as well as Democrats giving up what they want, until an agreement can ultimately be reached.

I'm not very familiar with the situation, but as far as I can tell the Gypsies that were evicted were not the legal owners of the land they were on. As far as I know there is nothing illegal happening here by any standards. While there is indeed a problem, it swings both ways and can't be reduced to Romanians being racist. Yes, some Romanians might be racist, but these Gypsies living in squalor, squatting on land that they don't own and making their living mostly through illegal means are making very little effort to integrate. Those of them that manage to get out of that misery end up living perfectly normal lives in the Romanian society.

I'm personally all in favor of any programs that would help them integrate, but as someone of Romanian origin I am also bothered by how easily we are accused of racism. It's not the race we have a problem with, it's the behavior.
More like a triumph of sense over nonsense.

The original tax break behind capital gains, was when a business had been improved and capital equipment had been bought, and it was sold, the gain in value was taxed at a lower rate than earned income.

This gave entrepreneurs the motive to sell their business and factories to those who would keep them going.

Since stock was part of the ownership the tax break applied to it also. But that has been subverted by the managers of funds and hedge funds to pay a minimal tax on the manipulation of equities and money. Also note the bonuses paid executives in companies. They pay ordinary tax on their salary, and get stock as a bonus. They get an option to buy the stock below market price, hold it 12 months and take the capital gains on it. In many cases the stock option is 2/3 more than their salary.
